Subject: [junit] Re: Conditional tearDown()


This I can do.  Thanks for the suggestion.

-Brian

--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, "Jason Rogers" <jacaetevha@f...> wrote:
> These are exceptional cases, right?  So, throw specific exceptions
that
> you can then catch in your test.
> 
> For instance, some of our tables prevent duplicate records.  We
catch
> that particular case and report it as an exceptional case.  If that
> happened to go wrong in the transaction when all else is fine we
know it
> in the test (and we explicitly test for that).  On the same
transaction
> there could be an attempt to enter a string for a number field, we
would
> catch that as a separate exception and report it -- and of course we
> would explicitly test for that case.
> 
> =jason
> [:question | ^One] 
> 
> -----Original Message-----
> From: Brian <br524@y...> [mailto:br524@y...] 
> Sent: Friday, January 03, 2003 1:04 PM
> To: junit@yahoogroups.com
> Subject: [junit] Re: Conditional tearDown()
> 
> 
> No, you have a good point.
> 
> The problem is that my test writes to the database, then I call the
> method that I'm unit testing which performs several database
functions
> within a transaction, then I read from the database again to test
the
> values.  The test could fail at any one of these three points.
> 
> Your suggestion of cleaning up code though made me look at the
> transactional method I was testing though...it turns out I was
missing
> a rollback() call, so thanks!  But that still doesn't solve the
> problem I have with three points of failure within my test.  If you
> have any ideas as to how to get around this, I'm all ears.
> 
> -Brian
> 
> --- In junit@yahoogroups.com, "Jason Rogers" <jacaetevha@f...>
wrote:
> > Could you not use the opportunity to clean up your code such that
> you
> > don't need to visually inspect the DB?  I realize that there may
be
> > times when you absolutely need the visual inspection (though I
can't
> > think of one off the bat), nevertheless, this seems like a subtle
> form
> > of test dependencies or spaghetti code, or some other code-smell. 
> Sorry
> > if that sounds harsh -- I am certainly not trying to be
judgemental,
> > just reflective.
> > 
> > =jason
> > [:question | ^One] 
> > 
> > -----Original Message-----
> > From: Kendall Collett [mailto:przkiie02@s...] 
> > Sent: Friday, January 03, 2003 12:41 PM
> > To: junit@yahoogroups.com
> > Sebjest: Re: [junit] Re: Conditional tearDown()
> > 
> > 
> > I could use a conditional clean-up in tearDown, for exactly the
same
> > reason
> > as Brian.
> > 
> > When I first ran into this issue; I didn't think of trying to make
> the
> > tearDown() clean-up conditional.  Instead, I adopted a convention
of
> > having
> > my setUp()s perform the clean-up for the next test.  In other
> words, for
> > a
> > given test I do a pre-clean instead of a post-clean.  I'm not sure
> if
> > that's
> > good or bad...
> > 
> > Kendall
> > 
> > ----- Original Message -----
> > From: Brian br524-at-yahoo.com br524-at-yahoo.com |Yahoo Work
> 20030102|
> > To: XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX
> > Sent: Friday, January 03, 2003 10:47
> > Subject: [junit] Re: Conditional tearDown()
> > 
> > 
> > I only have one test in the TestCase, and if it fails, I want to
> leave
> > the database in the state it was in when the test failed so I can
> > inspect what happened.
> > 
> > --- In junit@yahoogroups.com, Mike Clark <mike@c...> wrote:
> > > Brian  wrote:
> > >
> > > >I see in the TestResult class there's a method wasSuccessful().
> > From
> > > >within class that extends TestCase, I want to do something like
> > this:
> > > >
> > > >    public void tearDown()
> > > >    {
> > > >        TestResult result = createResult();
> > > >        if( result.wasSuccessful() )
> > > >        {
> > > >            System.out.println( "Clearing database" );
> > > >            clearDatabase( "1" );
> > > >        }
> > > >    }
> > > >
> > > >
> > >
> > > Is this intended to be more efficient than just clearing the
> > database
> > > every time the tearDown() method is invoked, or am I missing
> > something?
> > >
> > > Mike
> >
